Firehose http://exclaim.ca/feedNews 2018-02-18T16:00:00+00:00 Brayden Turenne <![CDATA[Insect Ark Marrow Hymns]]> http://exclaim.ca/music/article/insect_ark-marrow_hymns Marrow Hymns is one of both beauty and dread. The style of pl]]> The signature of Insect Ark's <em>Marrow Hymns</em> is one of both beauty and dread. The style of playing is subdued and relaxed, like a desert mirage, but beneath the facade of ease, there are hints of dark mystery to be unearthed.<br />  <br /> Nearly all of <em>Marrow Hymns</em> is bound by a singular dream state, rarely breaking from the spell. "In The Nest" and "Slow Ray" would be perfect matches to scenes out of a dark, dismal Western like Cormac McCarthy's, <em>Blood Meridian</em>, in which nomadic travellers brave the yawning expanse of the desolate landscape with a shrinking hope of salvation. "Skin Walker" provides some welcome surge of danger into the mix with its more abrupt stomp, momentarily breaking the mirage before falling back into the heat wave.<br />  <br /> "Sea Harps" is a melancholy orchestra of drawn-out strings, sounding gentle in a flowing wind, weightless and unreal, while "Tarnish" takes the listener out of their body and into the ethereal, where there is no foundation of rhythm to cling to.<br />  <br /> <em>Marrow Hymns</em> embodies a slow stream of atmosphere more than a series of distinct songs, resulting in a mostly uniform whole of elegant minimalism that gradually shifts and transforms into varying shapes, like clouds adrift in the sky. Insect Ark draw as much from the twang of country as from drone or doom, but produce something intoxicatingly unique in <em>Marrow Hymns</em>, which bears more similarities with experimental groups like Barn Owl or Godspeed You! Black Emperor than anything else.<img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/ExclaimCaAllArticles/~4/GLj9FSRGvgU" height="1" width="1" alt=""/> 2018-02-18T16:00:00+00:00 http://exclaim.ca/music/article/insect_ark-marrow_hymns Nilan Perera <![CDATA[Robbie Basho Live in Forli, Italy, 1982]]> http://exclaim.ca/music/article/robbie_basho-live_in_forli_italy_1982 Robbie Basho's world encompassed the whole school of American Primitive guitar (John Fahey, Leo Kottke, et al). His fingerstyle technique was without peer, as was his eccentric spirituality and presence.<br />  <br /> A truly unique force of nature, from changing his last name to honour an ancient, Zen-inspired Japanese poet, to a vibrant booming voice in song and a quasi-medieval dress code. His repertoire included music from the 13th century ('The Grail and the Lotus") to Indian classical music, all fed through Basho's own filters of personal mysticism.<br />  <br /> This release is a beautiful representation of his work performed in a beautiful 18th century hall to a small but appreciative audience in an even smaller Italian town. Basho's fingerpicking is clear and articulate, playing fast and furious on six- and 12-string acoustic guitars — and this is the one thing that is a bit regrettable. Recording acoustic instrumental guitar is a tricky business and this recording emphasised that. The sound is clear and, to be sure, not muddy or corrupted, but it is definitely a bit thin. However, the performance itself is very good, and one can really hear that he was happy to be there, playing semi-apologetic MC in quite passable Italian.<img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/ExclaimCaAllArticles/~4/DGidJEkbUII" height="1" width="1" alt=""/> 2018-02-18T15:00:00+00:00 http://exclaim.ca/music/article/robbie_basho-live_in_forli_italy_1982 Tom Beedham <![CDATA[​M.I. Blue The Garrison, Toronto ON, February 16]]> http://exclaim.ca/music/article/m_i_blue-the_garrison_toronto_on_february_16 Eschewing the presenter introductions that preceded each of the night's sets before — and with them the avuncular hyping instructions to "make some noise!" and "get louder!" — M.I. Blue approached the chatty crowd, took the mic and indicated that if this was going to work, everyone was going to have to tune in and get with the vibe: "Slow and mellow," Blue indicated.<br />  <br /> So when chatter at the bar didn't wane with the lapping tidal recordings and volume swells Blue cued up in the mix, it was time to shut it down and start from scratch. The downtempo neo-soul wanderings Blue deals in are brief and delicate meditations built to be absorbed through open attention and focused concentration, and Blue guided them with a rightfully uncompromising and assertive hand. But despite Blue's efforts to play on her own terms, unfortunately, the whole set was plagued with sound issues, so if it wasn't the bar noise interfering, the monitors weren't loud enough or a laptop sequence was miscued. Blue dazzled with a handful of new tracks nevertheless, and a calm patience permeated the room, illustrated by audience members swimming around in their own heads. <br> <blockquote class="instagram-media" data-instgrm-permalink="https://www.instagram.com/p/BfTrjOMnArI/" data-instgrm-version="8" style=" background:#FFF; border:0; border-radius:3px; box-shadow:0 0 1px 0 rgba(0,0,0,0.5),0 1px 10px 0 rgba(0,0,0,0.15); margin: 1px; max-width:658px; padding:0; width:99.375%; width:-webkit-calc(100% - 2px); width:calc(100% - 2px);"> <div style="padding:8px;"> <div style=" background:#F8F8F8; line-height:0; margin-top:40px; padding:50% 0; text-align:center; width:100%;"> <div style=" background:url(data:image/png;base64,); display:block; height:44px; margin:0 auto -44px; position:relative; top:-22px; width:44px;"> </div> </div> <p style=" color:#c9c8cd; font-family:Arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px; line-height:17px; margin-bottom:0; margin-top:8px; overflow:hidden; padding:8px 0 7px; text-align:center; text-overflow:ellipsis; white-space:nowrap;"><a href="https://www.instagram.com/p/BfTrjOMnArI/" style=" color:#c9c8cd; font-family:Arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px; font-style:normal; font-weight:normal; line-height:17px; text-decoration:none;" target="_blank">A post shared by Exclaim! (@exclaimdotca)</a> on <time datetime="2018-02-17T18:15:35+00:00" style=" font-family:Arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px; line-height:17px;">Feb 17, 2018 at 10:15am PST</time></p> </div> </blockquote> <script async defer src="//www.instagram.com/embed.js"></script><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/ExclaimCaAllArticles/~4/-8VKJzS-RPg" height="1" width="1" alt=""/> 2018-02-17T19:34:00+00:00 http://exclaim.ca/music/article/m_i_blue-the_garrison_toronto_on_february_16 Tom Beedham <![CDATA[OBUXUM The Garrison, Toronto ON, February 16]]> http://exclaim.ca/music/article/obuxum-the_garrison_toronto_on_february_16 The compositions Toronto-via-Somalia producer Muxubo Mohamed makes as OBUXUM are adventurously percussive, performance-based joints that effortlessly slam from patient dirges into throbbing house beats, from dizzily effected cowbells to trap-hacked marching snares on a dime, elsewhere floating righteous spoken word samples like Saul Williams' "This Type Love" over cloudy atmospheric swells.<br />  <br /> As Mohamed worked through her Wavelength set, returns to the rubbery, distorted progressions of 2015's <em>Luul</em> EP provided the staggering sensory jam a sense of continuity, but a shoddy patch cable continued to cut out, and just as it was all reaching its frenzied climax, her hardware dropped out completely from the room mix. But Mohamed took it all in stride, and after a brief if disruptive moment of confusion, when the issue resolved itself, she was all smiles, dusting off her shoulders and dancing harder than before, vibes infectious, the whole room right there with her.<br />  <blockquote class="instagram-media" data-instgrm-permalink="https://www.instagram.com/p/BfTrjOMnArI/" data-instgrm-version="8" style=" background:#FFF; border:0; border-radius:3px; box-shadow:0 0 1px 0 rgba(0,0,0,0.5),0 1px 10px 0 rgba(0,0,0,0.15); margin: 1px; max-width:658px; padding:0; width:99.375%; width:-webkit-calc(100% - 2px); width:calc(100% - 2px);"><div style="padding:8px;"> <div style=" background:#F8F8F8; line-height:0; margin-top:40px; padding:50% 0; text-align:center; width:100%;"> <div style=" background:url(data:image/png;base64,); display:block; height:44px; margin:0 auto -44px; position:relative; top:-22px; width:44px;"></div></div><p style=" color:#c9c8cd; font-family:Arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px; line-height:17px; margin-bottom:0; margin-top:8px; overflow:hidden; padding:8px 0 7px; text-align:center; text-overflow:ellipsis; white-space:nowrap;"><a href="https://www.instagram.com/p/BfTrjOMnArI/" style=" color:#c9c8cd; font-family:Arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px; font-style:normal; font-weight:normal; line-height:17px; text-decoration:none;" target="_blank">A post shared by Exclaim! (@exclaimdotca)</a> on <time style=" font-family:Arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px; line-height:17px;" datetime="2018-02-17T18:15:35+00:00">Feb 17, 2018 at 10:15am PST</time></p></div></blockquote> <script async defer src="//www.instagram.com/embed.js"></script><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/ExclaimCaAllArticles/~4/pcyqW57XvR0" height="1" width="1" alt=""/> 2018-02-17T19:32:00+00:00 http://exclaim.ca/music/article/obuxum-the_garrison_toronto_on_february_16 Tom Beedham <![CDATA[PLAZAS The Garrison, Toronto ON, February 16]]> http://exclaim.ca/music/article/plazas-the_garrison_toronto_on_february_16 As doors still welcomed new arrivals at Wavelength's freshly rebranded Winter Festival, Toronto-via-Vancouver performer Savana Salloum-Hedgecock's PLAZAS opened the festival and greeted audiences with a cozy electric blanket of nerdy, starry synth-pop songs for social outcasts. Glimpsing all your secret inner winter hellscapes through the distant lenses of observatories and Vancouver's SkyTrain lines, PLAZAS made an intimate space of the sparsely populated room, often addressing a far off "you" and ironically beckoning the subjects of her songs to "Come to morose with me," advising, "Romantics can't help themselves / So I can't help you anymore)."<br />  <br /> All packaged in sequined leotards, expressive dancing, and shimmering, pre-programmed sparkle-wave electronics, if you came early enough and snagged a cookie at the door, your crusty heart melted all over it.<br />   <blockquote class="instagram-media" data-instgrm-permalink="https://www.instagram.com/p/BfTrjOMnArI/" data-instgrm-version="8" style=" background:#FFF; border:0; border-radius:3px; box-shadow:0 0 1px 0 rgba(0,0,0,0.5),0 1px 10px 0 rgba(0,0,0,0.15); margin: 1px; max-width:658px; padding:0; width:99.375%; width:-webkit-calc(100% - 2px); width:calc(100% - 2px);"> <div style="padding:8px;"> <div style=" background:#F8F8F8; line-height:0; margin-top:40px; padding:50% 0; text-align:center; width:100%;"> <div style=" background:url(data:image/png;base64,); display:block; height:44px; margin:0 auto -44px; position:relative; top:-22px; width:44px;"> </div> </div> <p style=" color:#c9c8cd; font-family:Arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px; line-height:17px; margin-bottom:0; margin-top:8px; overflow:hidden; padding:8px 0 7px; text-align:center; text-overflow:ellipsis; white-space:nowrap;"><a href="https://www.instagram.com/p/BfTrjOMnArI/" style=" color:#c9c8cd; font-family:Arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px; font-style:normal; font-weight:normal; line-height:17px; text-decoration:none;" target="_blank">A post shared by Exclaim! (@exclaimdotca)</a> on <time datetime="2018-02-17T18:15:35+00:00" style=" font-family:Arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px; line-height:17px;">Feb 17, 2018 at 10:15am PST</time></p> </div> </blockquote> <script async defer src="//www.instagram.com/embed.js"></script><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/ExclaimCaAllArticles/~4/11T7avWIZyM" height="1" width="1" alt=""/> 2018-02-17T19:30:00+00:00 http://exclaim.ca/music/article/plazas-the_garrison_toronto_on_february_16 Brock Thiessen <![CDATA[Matthew Barber Returns with 'Phase of the Moon' ]]> http://exclaim.ca/music/article/matthew_barber_returns_with_phase_of_the_moon Matthew Barber has]]> Toronto singer-songwriter <a href="https://exclaim.ca/artists/matthew_barber">Matthew Barber</a> has revealed he's returning with a new album. Titled <i>Phase of the Moon</i>, the record will arrive via <a href="http://outside-music.com/label/" target="_blank">Outside Music</a> on May 4.<br /> <br /> The LP will mark the follow-up to 2014's <a href="http://exclaim.ca/Music/article/matthew_barber-big_romance"><i>Big Romance</i></a> and comes in the wake of 2016's <a href="https://exclaim.ca/music/article/matthew_and_jill_barber-the_family_album"><i>The Family Album</i></a> will sister Jill Barber.<br /> <br /> <i>Phase of the Moon</i> was self-produced by Matthew Barber, along with Ken Friesen (the Tragically Hip, Carly Rae Jepsen) handling the engineering.<br /> <br /> A press release explains the following of the new album:<br /> <br /> <i>The songs on </i>Phase of the Moon <i>were conceived in a tiny studio apartment in the quaint Paris neighbourhood of Montmartre where Matthew and his wife spent a month in early 2017. It came with a small upright piano and had thin walls, which could explain why piano songs sung in deeper, hushed tones feature prominently on the record. The winter sojourn in Europe provided a welcome respite from the all-consuming media madness back home, and coupled with a steady diet of existentialist reading material, served to foster a mood of almost contented melancholy that seeped into the songs and runs throughout the record. This mood is at times manifested in the form of a solitary searcher reflecting on what's come before and wondering what lies ahead, and at other times through words of support addressed to a concerned partner that reveal a commensurate plea for reassurance that everything's going to be ok. The quiet storm is punctuated by necessary and at times exuberant affirmations of love, hope and wonderment, and a spirit of embracing life in all its complexity endures.</i><br /> <br /> For a taste of that, you can hear the new album track "Back to You," which has arrived via a new Christopher Mills-directed video. You'll find it below, along with the album's tracklist and Barber's upcoming tour dates.<br /> <br /> <i>Phase of the Moon</i>:<br /> <br /> 1. Grateful For The Rain<br /> 2. Phase Of The Moon<br /> 3. Hanging On The Line<br /> 4. Maybe It's Love<br /> 5. Back To You<br /> 6. The Pathway<br /> 7. All In A Dream<br /> 8. A Living<br /> 9. The Painter<br /> 10. Take Good Care<br /> <br /> Tour dates:<br /> <br /> 03/02 Victoria, BC - Capital Ballroom<br /> 03/03 Vancouver, BC - The Imperial<br /> 03/05 Red Deer, AB - Bo's Bar and Grill<br /> 03/06 Lethbridge, AB - Geomatic Attic<br /> 03/08 Calgary, AB - Marquee <br /> 03/09 Edmonton, AB - Starlite Room<br /> 03/10 Saskatoon, SK - Capitol Music Club<br /> 03/12 Winnipeg, MB - Garrick Centre <br /> 03/14 St. Catharines, ON - The Warehouse <br /> 03/15 London, ON - Rum Runners Music Hall <br /> 03/16 Toronto, ON - Phoenix Concert Theatre<br /> 03/17 Montreal, QC - Cafe Campus<br /> <br />  <iframe allow="autoplay; encrypted-media" allowfullscreen="" frameborder="0" height="380" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/b-3PGKqhShY" width="560"></iframe><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/ExclaimCaAllArticles/~4/U_d2HaOjpek" height="1" width="1" alt=""/> 2018-02-16T21:40:00+00:00 http://exclaim.ca/music/article/matthew_barber_returns_with_phase_of_the_moon Sarah Murphy <![CDATA[​Vampire Weekend's Ezra Koenig Shares His 'Peter Rabbit' Song ]]> http://exclaim.ca/film/article/vampire_weekends_ezra_koenig_shares_his_peter_rabbit_song James Corden's rendition o]]> Last week, we heard <a href="https://exclaim.ca/artists/james_corden">James Corden</a>'s rendition of <a href="http://exclaim.ca/film/article/hear_james_cordens_peter_rabbit_song_written_by_vampire_weekends_ezra_koenig">"I Promise You"</a> from the <a href="http://exclaim.ca/film/article/parents_are_pissed_at_peter_rabbit_for_throwing_berries_at_an_old_man">allergy insensitive</a> adaptation of <em>Peter Rabbit</em>. The tune was penned by Ezra Koenig, and now the <a href="http://exclaim.ca/artists/vampire_weekend">Vampire Weekend</a> frontman has shared his own demo version of the same track.<br />  <br /> Aptly dubbed "I Promise You (Ezra's Demo)," the song is a saccharinely sweet piano cut, injected with some extra bounce thanks to bubbling drum machine effects.<br />  <br /> Listen to Koenig's contribution to the Will Gluck-directed film below.<br />  <br /> <em>Peter Rabbit</em> and the film's soundtrack are both out now.<br />  <br /> <iframe width="100%" height="380" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/YTqeDra5POw" frameborder="0" allow="autoplay; encrypted-media" allowfullscreen></iframe><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/ExclaimCaAllArticles/~4/HkW6RxYTf8g" height="1" width="1" alt=""/> 2018-02-16T20:07:00+00:00 http://exclaim.ca/film/article/vampire_weekends_ezra_koenig_shares_his_peter_rabbit_song Brock Thiessen <![CDATA[Hayden Treats 'Moving Careful' to Expanded 20th Anniversary Vinyl Reissue ]]> http://exclaim.ca/music/article/hayden_treats_moving_careful_to_expanded_20th_anniversary_vinyl_reissue Following an anniversary edition of <a href="https://exclaim.ca/music/article/hayden-everything_i_long_for_20"><i>Everything I Long For</i></a>, Canadian songwriting hero <a href="http://exclaim.ca/artists/hayden">Hayden</a> is giving his <i>Moving Careful</i> release the same treatment.<br /> <br /> On March 9, Hayden will release the 1996 EP as an expanded 20th anniversary edition, both on vinyl and digitally. It will mark the first vinyl pressing of the release since it initially arrived as a 10-inch.<br /> <br /> <i>Moving Careful</i> was originally recorded in the mid-'90s and released via Hardwood/Sonic Unyon in late 1996. For the expanded reissue, Side 2 of the release will include a series of rare recording captured between '94 and '96.<br /> <br /> In a statement, Hayden had this to say about the release:<br /> <br /> <em>After touring my debut, </em>Everything I Long For<em>, across Canada for the better part of two years from 1994-96, I celebrated its imminent International release by developing a strong dislike for the sound of my music. A major sticking point in my negotiations with Outpost Recordings (my US label at the time) was to have the ability to release singles and EPs on my own or through smaller labels. They agreed, and </em>Moving Careful <em>was born from late night obsessions on the third floor of a rented Victorian house in Toronto. Although much of my debut was recorded on a 4-track cassette, I was eager to get back to my Yamaha MT100 II, and very inspired by what Eric's Trip and Lou Barlow were doing at the time.</em><br /> <br /> Down below, you can check out the reissue's newly expanded tracklist, and that's its updated cover above.<br /> <br /> <i>Moving Careful - Plus Rarities</i>:<br /> <br /> 1. Pots and Pans<br /> 2. Stride<br /> 3. Middle of July<br /> 4. Old Fashioned Way<br /> 5. Half For Me<br /> 6. Choking<br /> 7. You are All I Have<br /> 8. A Fortune I'd Kept<br /> 9. Hazy<br /> 10. I Wake Up With Me<br /> 11. Mild<br /> 12. Winter Trip<br /> 13. Carry On Mentality<br /> 14. Wasting My Days Away<br />  <img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/ExclaimCaAllArticles/~4/g2p0B6qSDro" height="1" width="1" alt=""/> 2018-02-16T19:32:00+00:00 http://exclaim.ca/music/article/hayden_treats_moving_careful_to_expanded_20th_anniversary_vinyl_reissue Beth Bowles <![CDATA[Car Seat Headrest Twin Fantasy]]> http://exclaim.ca/music/article/car_seat_headrest-twin_fantasy Twin Fantasy, an album he labeled incomplete, on Bandca]]> In 2011, Car Seat Headrest released <em>Twin Fantasy</em>, an album he labeled incomplete, on Bandcamp. The DIY album, recorded in the back seat of a car, was unsupported by a label and featured poor production quality, but it resonated. Car Seat Headrest were making music on their own, and it garnered them swathes of listeners.<br />  <br /> Now, in 2018, Car Seat Headrest are re-releasing <em>Twin Fantasy</em> under Matador Records to show how much a band can evolve in seven years. <em>Twin Fantasy </em>still tells the tumultuous story of frontman Will Toledo's troubled romance with another man, but this re-recorded version shows significant musical growth — maybe even more than if the band released brand new music.<br />  <br /> Throughout <em>Twin Fantasy (2018)</em>, the guitar riffs are cleaner, the transitions are more fluid and Toledo's vocals sound less like he's in a tin can. That can maybe be attributed a higher budget, but a that wouldn't explain the small changes that were made to <em>Twin Fantasy</em>'s original form. At the beginning of  2018's "Beach Life-in-Death," the sound of a beer can opening and someone drinking starts the track; the beginning of "Bodys" is digitized, in contrast to its original intro;  and on "Cute Thing," Toledo sings, "Give me Frank Ocean's voice," instead of the original "Give me Dan Bejar's voice." It's all those small changes that prove Car Seat Headrest are constantly moving forward.<br />  <br /> The refurbishment of "Beach Life-in-Death," the album's second track, makes it a potential front-runner for the best rock song of 2018. Sure, that may be a bold statement so early in the year, but at a little over 13 minutes long, the track deals with such heady subject matter as the mundaneness of living, loving and dying; it's several different ideas, both instrumentally and lyrically, neatly wrapped in a single, cohesive package. In 2011, "Beach Life-in-Death," was a great track, but now, they've made it exceptional.<br />  <br /> It's a challenging album at parts, but those challenges are broken up by short, digestible moments that still provide moments of clarity. "Stop Smoking" is a quick and clear message of love, while "Nervous Young Inhumans" calls out all the crappy songwriters who only sing about girls without really understanding love. "Bodys" offers a smirk-worthy meta-awareness when Toledo sings: "Is it the chorus yet? / No, it's just the building of the verse, so when the chorus does come it'll be more rewarding." By breaking the fourth wall, it feels like Toledo is inviting us along for the ride.<br />  <br /> The age-old saying goes if something isn't broken, don't fix it, but the re-release of <em>Twin Fantasy</em> shows that, seven years later, Car Seat Headrest are capable of re-contextualizing their work in ways that cement the faith that we have in them as revolutionary musicians.<img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/ExclaimCaAllArticles/~4/jw1VIzpswBc" height="1" width="1" alt=""/> 2018-02-16T18:52:00+00:00 http://exclaim.ca/music/article/car_seat_headrest-twin_fantasy Luke Pearson <![CDATA[The Empire Line Rave]]> http://exclaim.ca/music/article/the_empire_line-rave Jonas Rönnberg, Christian Stadgaard and Isak Hansen (denizens all of Germany's experimental techno scene) make up the Empire Line, and their debut is a fittingly intrepid exploration of the murky overlappings of drone, techno and punk. Simply titled <em>Rave, </em>the album is best approached as a kind of mission statement for the group's deconstruction of the concept of rave and the broader role it plays in people's lives. It's perhaps more interesting conceptually than musically for those not already immersed in the goings-on of Berlin and Stockholm's techno scenes, but anyone interested in exploring the outer edges of rave and techno will find <em>Rave</em> edifying, at the very least.<br />  <br /> There's an appealing live-off-the-floor feel to the proceedings, its pre-programmed elements locking into each other with the kind of rhythmic push and pull not usually found in electronic music. This, in addition to Rönnberg's vocals (always buried in the mix, like they're being shouted from one end of a warehouse to the other — and they probably were), gives <em>Rave </em>a compellingly raw aesthetic, and when it all comes together, things sound great. The claustrophobic pulse of "Music for Catwalks" for instance, or "Fast Forward (intet glemt, intet tilgivet)", with its ragged and passionate vocals reminiscent of KMFDM (who definitely hover in the periphery here), display alluring glimpses of the group's potential.<br />  <br /> However, one gets the distinct feeling that the impact of the Empire Line's music is lessened significantly by its commitment to tape. The group initially garnered attention for their intense live performances, and there's a real sense of having missed out on the party here; it's music so rooted in scene and geography that it sounds almost incomplete outside of its socio-cultural context, and the group don't always make up for this lack musically. Much of <em>Rave </em>slides by without leaving a lasting impression beyond the group's obvious passion and commitment.<br />  <br /> The notion of retaining rave as a lived concept after the night is through is an interesting one that the Empire Line will hopefully translate into even more interesting music in the future. Until then, put on <em>Rave </em>while researching your next flight to Berlin.<img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/ExclaimCaAllArticles/~4/X-m0ThjICX4" height="1" width="1" alt=""/> 2018-02-16T18:50:00+00:00 http://exclaim.ca/music/article/the_empire_line-rave Ian Gormely <![CDATA[Everything Is Recorded Everything Is Recorded by Richard Russell]]> http://exclaim.ca/music/article/everything_is_recorded-everything_is_recorded_by_richard_russell As this debut album's title plainly spells out, Everything is Recorded is the new project from XL Recordings' founder Richard Russell. Its concept — pair the influential label-head with a slew of talented collaborators, many of whom are on his payroll, and see what happens — reads like the definition of artistic indulgence and hubris. Yet the record is a tasteful amalgam of its participants' prodigious talents.<br />  <br /> EIR bears a striking resemblance to This Mortal Coil, the gothic dream-pop project of 4AD founder Ivo Watts-Russell (no relation). Yet, where Watts-Russell was something more akin to a curator or executive producer, XL's Russell takes a far more hands-on approach. And he's no dilettante: Russell scored a surprise UK hit back in 1992 as Kicks Like a Mule and famously produced Gil-Scott Heron's final album, <em>I'm New Here</em>. Fitting XL's eclectic roster, <em>Everything Is Recorded by Richard Russell </em>touches on dub, soul, UK garage and bass music, among many other sounds.<br />  <br /> Born out of jam sessions held in the wake of Russell's hospitalization and recovery from full-body paralysis, loneliness is at the record's core. "There are moments in our lives that we feel completely alone," booms the slowed-down sample from preacher TD Jakes that opens the record, a motif that Russell disperses throughout the album's brisk 40-minute runtime.<br />  <br /> Still, his collaborators, including Kamasi Washington, Ibeyi, Syd, Damon Albarn and Owen Pallett, can't quite match the solitary feelings imbued in much of Russell's production. Many deliver star-making turns — Infinite, son of Ghostface Killah, turns in stellar performances on "Bloodshot Red Eyes" and "Be My Friend" — but even with egos firmly in check, songs like "She Said" featuring Obongjayar feel more concerned with the corporeal than the kind of spiritual searching in which Russell appears interested. There's a disconnect between some of the individual songs — which are strong across the board — and the record's higher purpose.<br />  <br /> Sampha, though, emerges as the record's MVP. Singing on four of the album's nine songs proper, each among the best of the lot, he and Russell connect on every level. Sampha's voice seamlessly blends into the Curtis Mayfield sample that forms the backbone of "Close But Not Quite." His warm vocals that anchor the album, bringing hope and uplift to dire straits.<br />  <br /> Working with any sort of group is a difficult undertaking under the best of circumstances; trying to herd a clutch of singularly minded artists such as this around a specific idea seems impossible. Yet, <em>Everything Is Recorded by Richard Russell</em> is a moving, beautiful album that offers community as a cure for loneliness. Even if at times he's somewhat overshadowed by his collaborators, Russell manages to have his voice shine through.<img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/ExclaimCaAllArticles/~4/Ji0fmzkeDG8" height="1" width="1" alt=""/> 2018-02-16T18:48:00+00:00 http://exclaim.ca/music/article/everything_is_recorded-everything_is_recorded_by_richard_russell Alex Hudson <![CDATA[Belle and Sebastian How to Solve Our Human Problems: Part 3]]> http://exclaim.ca/music/article/belle_and_sebastian-how_to_solve_our_human_problems_part_3 How to Solve Our Human Problems isn't so much an EP series as it is a]]> Belle and Sebastian's <em>How to Solve Our Human Problems</em> isn't so much an EP series as it is a single album broken into three serialized instalments. And the series has been getting stronger as it has progressed: after the hit-or-miss <em>Part 1</em> and the mostly solid <em>Part 2</em>, final instalment <em>Part 3</em> is the strongest of the bunch.<br /> <br /> Much like the other EPs, <em>Part 3</em> is stylistically all over the map, touching on sounds that B&S have explored throughout their 22-year career. Opener "Poor Boy" is a disco-dazzled duet with funky bass syncopations, while "There Is an Everlasting Song" is a gentle folk ditty and the soaring baroque pop of "Everything Is Now (Part Two)" is far superior sequel to a directionless cut from <em>Part 1</em>.<br />  <br /> Intriguingly, the opulent strings and female guest vocalists of "Too Many Tears" and "Best Friend" make those tracks sound like particularly strong outtakes from frontman Stuart Murdoch's <em>God Help the Girl </em>project.<br /> <br /> Releasing <em>How to Solve Our Human Problems </em>as three five-song EPs presumably helped to maximize B&S's press coverage, although it's tempting to imagine how it might have sounded as a single album. With a few of the duds from prior EPs removed, this could have been a very solid 10-track album. In any case, this project is going out on a high note.<img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/ExclaimCaAllArticles/~4/v54Lz3l_oW4" height="1" width="1" alt=""/> 2018-02-16T18:44:00+00:00 http://exclaim.ca/music/article/belle_and_sebastian-how_to_solve_our_human_problems_part_3 Cosette Schulz <![CDATA[Born Ruffians Uncle, Duke and the Chief]]> http://exclaim.ca/music/article/born_ruffians-uncle_duke_and_the_chief Uncle, Duke and the Chief, the latest offering from Toronto-by-way-of-Midland, Ontario's Bo]]> <em>Uncle, Duke and the Chief,</em> the latest offering from Toronto-by-way-of-Midland, Ontario's Born Ruffians, truly feels like a return to form. It welcomes back original drummer Steve Hamelin (who had taken leave from the band to pursue a degree), and with the original line-up back in play, it seems inevitable that the charm and youthful energy of their debut <em>Red, Yellow and Blue</em> would also surface. Though the Ruffians' palette has expanded greatly since their primary-coloured start, on <em>Uncle, Duke and The Chief</em> — a title charmingly made up of each members' (singer/guitarist Luke Lalonde, bassist Mitch Derosier and Hamelin) father's nicknames — their past peeks through, exuberance and all.<br />  <br /> Opening tune "Forget Me," reportedly written through tears on the day Bowie died, starts with an acoustic strum as Lalonde begins to sing, handclaps working as initial percussion before Hamelin and Derosier join in. The lyrics, largely dealing with death ("Someday / a white light / will come for you / to comfort you") are certainly some of the Ruffians' darkest (see "waiting on a sun that's never rising" in "Fade to Black"), but there is sweetness still. It's a warm welcome to the album, and immediately seems to boast the familiar boisterousness of the Ruffians of old. The doo-wop-ish "Miss You" follows, with all three Ruffians harmonizing as the song gains momentum and the energy increases. "Side Tracked" is a standout, softening the pace a bit and allowing Derosier to play a delightful scale-skipping bass line.<br />  <br /> You'll want a hand to hold during the simple and sincere "Love Too Soon" as it swims in a sea of warm bass, gentle tambourine taps, organ swells and just the sweetest addition of whistling that threatens to make it all too much (but doesn't). It certainly feels like a companion to much-loved tune "Little Garcon," but without the foot-stomping shout-along ending. The Ruffians even somehow get away with a millennial whoop, found throughout "Tricky" — thank Lalonde's very fun vocal delivery (asking "When are you gonna come hooooome?" in that exaggerated deep register) and the song's terribly infectious energy for that.<br />  <br /> It's the pairing of melodies that comfort, and lyrics that threaten to take it away, that really make this album. Where 2015's <em>RUFF</em> spoke of being disheartened and disillusioned in the creative world, <em>Uncle, Duke and the Chief</em> is honest about life — its ups, its downs, its changes and rearrangements, procrastination and stress, and certainly its inevitable end. The simple production, with Lalonde's untamed vocals clear as a bell and Hamelin's homecoming, lets the joy that played a part in the process of making the short and sweet <em>Uncle, Duke and the Chief</em> shine evidently through.<img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/ExclaimCaAllArticles/~4/cGoUzWzPkoU" height="1" width="1" alt=""/> 2018-02-16T18:42:00+00:00 http://exclaim.ca/music/article/born_ruffians-uncle_duke_and_the_chief Sarah Murphy <![CDATA[​Rich Aucoin Plots North American Bicycle Tour, Shares "The Fear" ]]> http://exclaim.ca/music/article/rich_aucoin_plots_north_american_bicycle_tour_shares_the_fear Rich Aucoin is gearing up for the release of his]]> <a href="http://exclaim.ca/artists/rich_aucoin">Rich Aucoin</a> is gearing up for the release of his <em><a href="http://exclaim.ca/music/article/rich_aucoin_announces_hold_ep_shares_new_song_via_text">Hold <span style="font-style:normal;">EP</span></a></em> next month, and he's just mapped out some exciting tour plans in support of the new record.<br />  <br /> Aucoin will be performing a run of Canadian tour dates, before hopping on his bike and cycling across the U.S. this spring — for a good cause. Turns out he was even more generous than we thought — like, to the tune of $100 million.<br />  <br /> The 6 God has finally unveiled the clip, which was directed by Karena Evans and shot in Miami. It opens with a string of title cards, stating: "The budget for this video was $996,631.90. We gave it all away. Don't tell the label."<br />  <br /> From there, we see footage of Drake covering a whole supermarket's grocery bill, awarding students scholarships and literally handing out stacks of cash to those he deems deserving.<br />  <br /> Watch the philanthropic clip below.<br />  <br /> <iframe allow="autoplay; encrypted-media" allowfullscreen="" frameborder="0" height="380" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/XUqRem0W8L8" width="100%"></iframe><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/ExclaimCaAllArticles/~4/7Nco1M7cnnw" height="1" width="1" alt=""/> 2018-02-16T16:32:00+00:00 http://exclaim.ca/music/article/drake_gives_out_almost_1_million_in_gods_plan_video Kevin Scott <![CDATA[Black Panther Directed by Ryan Coogler]]> http://exclaim.ca/film/article/black_panther-directed_by_ryan_coogler Though the MCU may have been predicated on striking a delicate balance between its expanding array of superheroes, there were always bound to be peaks and valleys amongst its output. Soaring magnificently into the former category is Ryan Coogler's <em>Black Panther</em>, which manages to explore new textures and reveal greater layers in an already saturated genre while still delivering the kind of excitement and thrills we've come to expect. In the process of scaling these wondrous heights, it might just plant a flag as the new pinnacle to aspire to for all future superhero films.<br /> <br /> It all starts with its main character, or rather, characters: as central as the Black Panther himself — T'Challa (Chadwick Boseman) — is, his home country of Wakanda in Africa plays a huge role, too. In an animated introduction, we learn all about the land's majesty and secrets, including the fact that the nation was struck by a meteorite years ago. This event bestowed upon its people the valuable and powerful mineral Vibranium, a key component in Wakanda's advanced technologies. Then we're momentarily transported to 1992 Oakland, where T'Challa's father, King T'Chaka (John Kani), is forced to dispose of rogue Wakandan N'Jobu (Sterling K. Brown) in an event that will have great reverberations many years later.<br /> <br /> Back in present day, T'Challa is mourning the loss of T'Chaka from the events of <em>The Avengers: Civil War</em> and preparing to become the new king of Wakanda. But of course, evil never sleeps, and before long T'Challa is headed to South Korea to track down arms dealer Ulysses Klaue (Andy Serkis), who has stolen a Wakandan artefact from a museum. He's assisted in the robbery by the aptly named Erik Killmonger (Michael B. Jordan), who turns out to both be more dangerous than Klaue and to have ties to Wakanda that cause him to set his sights on T'Challa's throne. The film's populated with a number of rich supporting characters, which gives all its actors at least one moment to shine.<br /> <br /> T'Challa's ex Nakia (Lupita Nyong'o) is seemingly always coming to his rescue as a member of the all-female special forces Dora Milaje, alongside the group's lethal leader Okoye (Danai Gurira). T'Challa's 16-year old sister Shuri (Letitia Wright) could put Q to shame with the kind of innovative gadgetry she's able to produce. Elsewhere, Forest Whitaker's Zuri is a Wakandan mystic who leads the various tribes in rituals, Martin Freeman has more to do this time around than in <em>Civil War</em> as CIA agent Everett K. Ross and <em>Get Out</em>'s Daniel Kaluuya is a close friend and advisor of T'Challa's.<br /> <br /> Throughout it all, there are moments of grandeur and awe — such as the initial descent into the sprawling and vibrant Wakanda, a nation cleverly hidden from the prying eyes of outsiders — but alongside the requisite assortment of chases through the streets, brutal battles, daring escapes and inevitable climactic showdowns, there are quieter moments, like a ceremony that transports T'Challa to visit his ancestors, that are more spiritual and introspective. Aside from fighting the obvious villains and external forces, it's surprising and refreshing to also find T'Challa twisted in inner turmoil over the responsibility his nation bears in assisting others with their power and wealth.<br /> <br /> Despite everything that's circling around them, Coogler never loses sight of the central conflict between T'Challa and Killmonger, slowly revealing their shared history until it's nearly boiled over to Shakespearean proportions. While Boseman lends great weight and a focused intensity to the title character, Jordan nearly manages to steal the movie with his stylish hairdo, ripped physique and the kind of motivation that almost makes you sympathize with his villain.<br /> <br /> This is yet another spectacular achievement for Coogler, who has been showcasing his directing prowess and steadily amassing fans since <em>Fruitvale Station</em> kicked the door open for <em>Creed</em>, as he continues to find larger audiences without losing any of his storytelling panache or visual flair. One can only wonder what Coogler will do next after this film surely cements him as one of Hollywood's greatest young talents behind the camera.<img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/ExclaimCaAllArticles/~4/XkbQcwCdaQ0" height="1" width="1" alt=""/> 2018-02-16T16:27:00+00:00 http://exclaim.ca/film/article/black_panther-directed_by_ryan_coogler Sarah Murphy <![CDATA[​Justin Bieber and Quavo Added to NBA All-Star Celebrity Game ]]> http://exclaim.ca/music/article/justin_bieber_and_quavo_added_to_nba_all-star_celebrity_game The NBA All-Star Weekend kicks off today with the annual celebrity game, and a couple of high-profile names have just been added to the roster.<br />  <br /> <a href="https://exclaim.ca/artists/justin_bieber">Justin Bieber</a> and <a href="https://exclaim.ca/artists/quavo">Quavo</a> have both been recruited for Team Clippers, joining the likes of <em>Stranger Things </em>star Caleb McLaughlin, Nick Cannon and <em>Property Brother </em>Drew Scott. Now the Canadian horror/comedy collective has shed further light on why the streaming behemoth effectively destroyed the launch of their latest project David and Goliath style.<br /> <br /> Speaking to Exclaim!, Astron-6's Conor Sweeney says YouTube yanked their entire series just hours after its launch — and completely disabled the <i>Divorced Dad</i> YouTube page — over a joke used in the "My Sis" episode that involved terrorist organization ISIS.<br /> <br /> "So YouTube entirely disabled our account and videos, because in the episode the running joke is that <i>Divorced Dad</i> is accidentally donating to ISIS all along," Sweeney explains. "We don't know what specifically they disagreed with, but the phone numbers we used for the donation jokes are dead phone numbers that used to belong to family landlines that no longer exist. "<br /> <br /> Considering the types of explicit and extreme content you can regularly find all over YouTube, a satirical Canadian comedy show would seem like the least of its worries. However, that didn't stop YouTube from swiftly removing <i>Divorced Dad</i> from its service.<br /> <br /> "This truly makes no sense to me, and we are such a bizarre target for YouTube to pick," Sweeney says. "I think YouTube is existing in an incredibly troublesome morality/creativity paradox. Logan Paul videotaped the corpse of a suicide victim for shock value and laughs. David Duke has his own YouTube page with tens of thousands of followers. Teenagers film themselves kicking the shit out of each other and bullying their peers. ISIS supporters upload songs and tributes to the organization. Serial killer worshippers post tributes, and on and on. <br /> <br /> "More than anything, it's puzzling that they targeted a satirical comedy web-series that clearly is not towing the line for ISIS. It sets such a weird precedent that it makes their message beyond troubling."<br /> <br /> At this point, Astron-6 is unsure when <i>Divorced Dad</i> will be back online. Unless YouTube fixes the situation and unblocks the account/videos, Sweeney says they will try to go to another service such as Vimeo.<img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/ExclaimCaAllArticles/~4/GcJpVddhwN4" height="1" width="1" alt=""/> 2018-02-16T15:00:00+00:00 A story has now resurfaced regarding an alleged police investigation that involved an underage concertgoer being found outside a Hedley concert in London, ON, who had been drugged and possibly raped in 2005.<br /> <br /> Rob Bazinet worked at London's beloved all-ages venue the Embassy for 11 years, serving as its general manager until the venue burned down in 2009. At the time, Bazinet was so synonymous with the venue that he earned the nickname Embassy Rob. (He has since taken the surname Houde through marriage and now works as a licensed security officer.)<br /> <br /> Speaking on the phone with Exclaim!, Bazinet recalled vivid details about an unnerving Hedley performance at the Embassy when the group were first starting out.<br /> <br /> The show — which took place on September 18, 2005 (as confirmed by a <a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20050923201204/http://hedleyonline.com:80/web/news/index.php" target="_blank">Web Archive capture</a> of the band's official website) — was part of the band's first cross-Canada tour after Jacob Hoggard took third place on <em>Canadian Idol</em>. At the time, the lineup for Hedley included Hoggard alongside guitarist Dave Rosin, bassist Tommy Mac and drummer Chris Crippin.<br /> <br /> "All day, they were jerks to everybody," Bazinet recalls. "The way they treated women and fans and even the bar staff was horrendous."<br /> <br /> He continues, "We were an all-ages venue. So we would have people as young as 14 at concerts. Now, with the Hedley show, they knew that going in. I made it very specific that they knew, and that we had black X's on the hands for minors so that if they wanted to buy drinks for girls or flirt with girls, we gave them the knowledge of age and below age. So they knew this going in."<br /> <br /> After their performance, Bazinet noticed something was strange when he went to check on the band in the green-room apartment above the venue.<br /> <br /> "I went up as part of my job to see if everything was okay, make sure that none of our equipment was up there accidentally, make sure the rider had been fully fulfilled and that the night was over," he says. "When I got up there, I went to check — and usually I'd check the whole space — but one of the bedrooms had the door shut. And I went to go check it, and the rest of the band got in the way."<br /> <br /> Though Bazinet doesn't remember which member of the band was in the room, he claims the remaining members of Hedley barricaded him from entering. "The feeling I had at the time was that I would've had to force my way into that room."<br /> <br /> Bazinet assumed the member in the bedroom just wanted privacy, so he went back downstairs to the bar. The way the Embassy was set up, he couldn't see when the band actually left, Bazinet explains, but at some point they packed up and left the green room. Then the police arrived, according to Bazinet.<br /> <br /> "They had found a young woman, unconscious with no shoes by the TD Bank, which was a block away," he recalls. "They took her to the hospital, they ran a blood test on her because they thought she might be drunk or on drugs, and it came back that there was rohypnol [known as a date rape drug] in her system."<br /> <br /> The police linked the girl to the Embassy because of the stamp on her hand.  <br /> <br /> "They went upstairs, we gave them permission to go through the green room. They found her shoes in the green room," Bazinet says, recalling that the shoes were "little leopard-print flats." The police contacted the girl's parents, seeking permission to utilize a rape kit.<br /> <br /> "She woke up, refused permission, and the investigation stopped," Bazinet adds. "The police couldn't do anything."<br /> <br /> Doing their due diligence, the police kept the Embassy's green room cordoned off for a week, according to Bazinet. "They came in two or three times, did things and left," he says.<br /> <br /> When Bazinet reached out to the police for a report, they wouldn't release the girl's name. He also remembers that she had an X on her hand, suggesting she was below the legal drinking age.<br /> <br /> "From what I understand, the girl was underage. So her name is sealed. But there's a police report from that night that says Hedley is the suspect."<br /> <br /> Exclaim! has contacted the London police department seeking more information about the alleged incident.<br /> <br /> With their green room taped off, the staff of the Embassy were repeatedly asked questions by patrons about what happened, and for a little while, the staff was talking about it.<br /> <br /> "Our promoter and the owner of the club, were sent letters from a law firm, and they said that the talking about Hedley was to immediately stop, or they would sue," Bazinet recalls. "And it was on behalf of Hedley, their management and their label. I read the letter, but I was never given a copy. I don't know if there are still copies."<br /> <br /> Because of the letter, the Embassy's staff were told that if they spoke out about the alleged Hedley incident they would be fired. However, when the allegations about Hedley popped up online earlier this week, Bazinet made his public Facebook page readily available on Twitter.<br /> <br /> "It seems like the band is very careful about ages," Bazinet says of his recent conversations with their other alleged victims. "Are they just really creepy guys and they're running that line between creep and rapist? I don't know."<br /> <br /> Bazinet recalls making small talk with the band in London before the group started acting out towards the Embassy staff.<br /> <br /> "They asked things like the ages of the people coming to the bar, they asked about the laws in Ontario and stuff," he says. "At the time, it seemed like conversation. It was like, 'Oh all-ages shows, you guys must have problems with staff members sleeping with underage girls,' and we would say, 'No, we mark them this way.'<br /> <br /> "Then somebody brought up that in Ontario at the time the legal age for sex was 16, and things like that got brought up. They were like, 'Oh we didn't know that.' It seemed at first like they were being tourists as a band, and they didn't really know what life in Ontario was like. And the next thing you know, we're all losers and they started doing whatever they want."<br /> <br /> Bazinet says he's been contacted by women from Vancouver, Ottawa and Toronto, all of whom have horror stories about the members of Hedley but are too afraid to speak out. Exclaim! has also received accounts of alleged misconduct from women who wish to remain anonymous.<br /> <br /> Earlier this week, the hashtag <a href="http://exclaim.ca/music/article/fans_urge_junos_to_drop_hedley_as_sexual_misconduct_allegations_surface_on_twitter">#outHedley2k18</a> emerged on Twitter as numerous people shared allegations about sexual misconduct from the members of the band. They <a href="https://exclaim.ca/music/article/hedley_respond_to_sexual_misconduct_allegations_cancel_junos_appearance">responded with a statement about the allegations</a>, but their performance at the Junos was cancelled while other partners like Air Canada have cancelled promotions with the band. That said, Hedley are still forging ahead with their cross-Canada tour. Their show in Brandon, MB, on Friday (February 16) has <a href="http://exclaim.ca/music/article/hedley_ban_press_from_ongoing_tour">banned all press</a> from attending.<br /> <br /> <em>[Ed. Note: A previous version of this article contained certain Embassy staff members' names. As per their request, we have now removed their names from the article following its initial publication.]</em><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/ExclaimCaAllArticles/~4/aKre3MsRqOI" height="1" width="1" alt=""/> 2018-02-16T00:23:00+00:00 http://exclaim.ca/music/article/hedley_were_investigated_for_allegedly_drugging_underage_concertgoer Brock Thiessen <![CDATA['Transparent' Cuts Ties with Jeffrey Tambor Following Sexual Harassment Claims ]]> http://exclaim.ca/film/article/transparent_cuts_ties_with_jeffrey_tambor_following_sexual_harassment_allegations Following a series of <a href="https://exclaim.ca/film/article/jeffrey_tambor_leaves_transparent_following_sexual_harassment_allegations">sexual harassment allegations</a>, <i>Transparent</i> star Jeffrey Tambor has officially been cut from the show.<br /> <br /> As <a href="https://deadline.com/2018/02/jeffrey-tambor-out-transparent-amazon-series-harassment-investigation-1202290473/" target="_blank"><i>Deadline</i></a> reports, Amazon confirmed his departure today, saying Tambor would not be coming back for the fifth season of <i>Transparent</i>.<br /> <br /> As previously reported, at least three women accused Tambor of sexual harassment while on the set of the hit Amazon series, including the actor's former assistant Van Barnes and co-star Trace Lysette.<br /> <br /> "I have great respect and admiration for Van Barnes and Trace Lysette, whose courage in speaking out about their experience on <i>Transparent</i> is an example of the leadership this moment in our culture requires," show creator <a href="https://exclaim.ca/artists/jill_soloway">Jill Soloway</a> told <i>Deadline</i>. "We are grateful to the many trans people who have supported our vision for <i>Transparent</i> since its inception and remain heartbroken about the pain and mistrust their experience has generated in our community."<br /> <br /> Soloway added, "We are taking definitive action to ensure our workplace respects the safety and dignity of every individual, and are taking steps to heal as a family."<br /> <br /> At this point, it's unclear when the fifth season of <i>Transparent</i> will air or if it will be the show's final season.<img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/ExclaimCaAllArticles/~4/cVYA8vGjKDY" height="1" width="1" alt=""/> 2018-02-15T22:08:00+00:00 http://exclaim.ca/film/article/transparent_cuts_ties_with_jeffrey_tambor_following_sexual_harassment_allegations Calum Slingerland <![CDATA[Grimes Now Says to Not Expect a New Album Anytime Soon Because the "Music Industry Is Trash" ]]> http://exclaim.ca/music/article/grimes_says_no_music_any_time_soon_after_all As the calendar rolled over to February, it came with plans of a new album from <a href="http://exclaim.ca/artists/grimes">Grimes</a>, who told a fan that an <em><a href="http://exclaim.ca/music/article/grimes-art_angels">Art Angels</a> </em>follow-up <a href="http://exclaim.ca/music/article/grimes_to_release_new_album_this_year">would arrive later this year</a>. Staff <![CDATA[Five Films That Share Themes with Donizetti's 'L'elisir d'amore' ]]> http://exclaim.ca/film/article/five_films_that_share_themes_with_donizettis_lelisir_damore Promotional consideration provided by Cineplex.

There are plenty of operas a]]> <em>Promotional consideration provided by Cineplex</em>.<br /> <br /> There are plenty of operas about unrequited love, and arguably just as many to feature magic and witchcraft. Still, few have had quite the same impact on pop culture as Gaetano Donizetti's <em>L'elisir d'amore</em> (<em>The Elixir of Love</em>).<br /> <br /> The piece, which debuted in 1832 at the Teatro della Canobbiana in Milan, shares plenty of familiar beats with modern romantic comedies, as a man attempts to woo his lover with a magic potion.<br /> <br /> In addition to its familiar premise, <em>L'elisir d'amore </em>also feels familiar because of its stunning character development and the fact that it's actually funny.<br /> <br /> Cineplex broadcast a live performance of <em>L'elisir d'amore </em>by the Metropolitan Opera in select theatres across Canada on February 10, and will air encores on March 17, March 19, March 21, March 24 and April 1. To prepare you for the show, we've drummed up five films that share similar themes with the piece.<br /> <br /> <br /> <br /> <strong><em>Love Potion No. 9 </em>(1992)</strong><br /> <br /> <iframe allow="autoplay; encrypted-media" allowfullscreen="" frameborder="0" height="360" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/uh6ir2m5SLw" width="640"></iframe><br /> Before she was a household name, Sandra Bullock starred in a number of semi-obscure rom-coms. Among them was <em>Love Potion No. 9 </em>— the directorial debut from <em>My Cousin Vinny</em> screenwriter Dale Launer. Proving just how far back love potions go in pop culture, the film takes its name from the 1959 song by the Clovers. In it, Sandy plays a lovesick scientist who tries out a potion that makes her irresistible to the opposite sex.<br /> <br /> <br /> <br /> <strong><em>Practical Magic </em>(1998)</strong><br /> <br /> <iframe allow="autoplay; encrypted-media" allowfullscreen="" frameborder="0" height="360" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/R7uixLkpjPs" width="640"></iframe><br /> <br /> For some reason, Sandra Bullock's early career is littered with films about spinster witches using magic for romance. In <em>Practical Magic</em>, she and Nicole Kidman play witch sisters who are doomed to never find love. In the film, she develops "Amas Veritas" — a hyper-specific anti-love spell intended to fend off a man she doesn't think exists. It's the opposite intention, but has the same effect.<br /> <br /> <br /> <br /> <strong><em>The 40-Year-Old Virgin</em> (2005)</strong><br /> <br /> <iframe allow="autoplay; encrypted-media" allowfullscreen="" frameborder="0" height="360" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/KUT64PctyNw" width="640"></iframe><br /> <br /> Of course, <em>L'elisir d'amore</em> is not just a film about potions. On a deeper level, it's really about the desperate things people will do for unrequited love. One can't help but be reminded of Steve Carrell's bumbling foibles in the wildly successful Judd Apatow comedy <em>The 40-Year-Old Virgin</em>, which showcases the ridiculous lengths one man will go to for some romantic attention.<br /> <br /> <br /> <br /> <strong><em>Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince </em>(2009)</strong><br /> <br /> <iframe allow="autoplay; encrypted-media" allowfullscreen="" frameborder="0" height="360" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/jpCPvHJ6p90" width="640"></iframe><br /> <br /> When potions are involved, there's no better place to look than the <em>Harry Potter</em> franchise. The sixth film in the series, 2009's <em>Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince</em>, Ron Weasley accidentally ingests Amortentia. The unbelievably powerful elixir causes its consumer to become overwhelmingly infatuated with the person who administered it. That said, the potion cannot recreate true love — only obsession.<br /> <br /> <br /> <strong><em>The Love Witch</em> (2016)</strong><br /> <br /> <iframe allow="autoplay; encrypted-media" allowfullscreen="" frameborder="0" height="360" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/vXOmzA56E40" width="640"></iframe><br /> <br /> The cyclical nature of pop culture means the concept of love magic was made retro with Anna Biller's cult classic 2016 film <em>The Love Witch</em>. An homage to the Technicolor films of the 1960s, <em>The Love Witch</em> is a bright, vintage horror comedy about, well, a love witch who uses her abilities to make men fall in love with her.<img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/ExclaimCaAllArticles/~4/KR75ZPmS_c0" height="1" width="1" alt=""/> 2018-02-15T18:47:00+00:00 http://exclaim.ca/film/article/five_films_that_share_themes_with_donizettis_lelisir_damore Calum Slingerland <![CDATA[August Greene "Black Kennedy"]]> http://exclaim.ca/music/article/august_greene-black_kennedy Common, keyboard whiz  Last month, hip-hop vet <a href="http://exclaim.ca/artists/common">Common</a>, keyboard whiz <a href="http://exclaim.ca/artists/robert_glasper">Robert Glasper</a> and master beathsmith <a href="http://exclaim.ca/artists/karriem_riggins">Karriem Riggins</a> announced plans to come together as <a href="http://exclaim.ca/artists/august_greene">August Greene</a>. Following up their debut single <a href="https://exclaim.ca/music/article/common_robert_glasper_and_karriem_riggins_team_up_as_august_greene">"Optimistic,"</a> the freshly formed trio have shared another new track.<br /> <br /> Titled "Black Kennedy," the laid-back cut can be heard in the player below.<br /> <br /> As Riggins said in a statement, "The process of creating this song gave me chills... It is a theme that represents royalty and brilliance. It also has J Dilla's influences, and it reminded us of the great times spent with him creating music."<br /> <br /> Common added, "For many people the Kennedy family symbolizes royalty and represents power, style, and influence. "It is a song of motivation, inspiration, perseverance and black excellence."<br /> <br /> August Greene's self-titled debut album will arrive March 9 through Amazon Music. <br /> <br /> Common last delivered <em><a href="http://exclaim.ca/music/article/common-black_america_again">Black America Again</a> </em>in 2016, which featured both Riggins and Glasper. Ignorant comments from Recording Academy president Neil Portnow resulted in the <a href="https://exclaim.ca/music/article/grammys_president_neil_portnow_announces_task_force_to_address_bias_against_women">formation of a task force</a> to counter bias against women. Today, we get the first revelation from their research — only 21 percent of the Grammys voting body identify as women.<br /> <br /> According to <a href="http://variety.com/2018/biz/news/recording-academy-issues-positive-numbers-on-female-representation-but-admits-its-not-enough-1202700240/" target="_blank"><em>Variety</em></a>, the Recording Academy sent a report to its membership. In addition to the shockingly low number of voters, the letter also revealed that only 11 percent of its Producers & Engineers Wing are women.<br /> <br /> A study suggests that only 12 percent of the total population of music creators identify as women, so the Grammys conceded that this bafflingly low statistic "reflects that of the music community." Still, they added that they need to do better. <br /> <br /> "It's not enough to reflect the community," the letter added. "We must be leaders in moving our industry toward greater inclusion and representation. Women are 50% of our world. We need their voice and presence at every level."<br /> <br /> After 17 percent of the Grammys were awarded to women this year, Music Academy president Neil Portnow said that women needed to <a href="https://exclaim.ca/music/article/grammys_president_says_women_need_to_step_up_after_men_win_most_of_the_awards">"step up"</a> if they wanted more recognition. Following an enormous outcry, he's since apologized for the <a href="https://exclaim.ca/music/article/grammys_president_says_he_regrets_telling_women_to_step_up">statements</a>.
